item.title: A 2026 Outlook: Markets, Macro Turbulence, and Cryptoâ€™s Maturation
item.content:encoded: This essay frames 2026 as a year of heightened geopolitical and macro uncertainty that forces crypto to mature: away from meme-driven speculation and toward â€œvalueâ€ via tokenization, privacy infrastructure, stablecoin expansion, and a renewed focus on DeFi. It argues that hard assets and real-world settlement rails gain importance as AI agents proliferate and governments deepen their role in digital marketsâ€”making autonomy, clear thinking, and selective risk-taking the core survival strategy.

item.title: The Data Stackâ€™s Next Form Factor: Multi-Agent Systems
item.content:encoded: Traditional data platforms rely on centralized monoliths and complex engineering pipelines that often create bottlenecks for business decision-makers. This article introduces Da2a, an open-source prototype that proposes a decentralized, agentic architecture where specialized Domain Agents (e.g., Marketing, E-commerce) collaborate through a Root Orchestrator using the Agent-to-Agent (A2A) protocol. By treating data sources as autonomous experts that communicate via standardized "agent cards" rather than static tables, Da2a demonstrates how multi-agent systems can intuitively solve complex cross-domain problems, offering a scalable and insight-focused alternative to rigid data warehousing.

item.title: â€œPerfectâ€ AI Code Wonâ€™t Fix Your Legacy Stack
item.content:encoded: AI code generation isnâ€™t the revolution itâ€™s marketed to be. While it accelerates greenfield projects, most real-world teams operate inside complex, evolving systems where maintenance, context, and trust matter more than first-draft speed. The true leverage of AI lies not in producing â€œperfectâ€ code, but in building processes that assume imperfection and continuously improve software over time.

item.title: Tackling The $44B Efficiency Gap In Global Cloud Computing
item.content:encoded: Enterprises are wasting upwards of $44 billion on cloud spending due to a legacy model of over-provisioning. The NodeLink model utilizes the RAM and CPU in the NX1 and also the internet bandwidth already sitting idle in homes.

item.title: HackerNoon Projects of the Week: QuantumLayer, Ekstra AI, & ComLab
item.content:encoded: This weekâ€™s Projects of the Week spotlights three standout entries from the Proof of Usefulness Hackathon. QuantumLayer embeds climate risk into software via API, Ekstra AI delivers privacy-first foot traffic insights for small businesses, and ComLab transforms scattered user feedback into actionable product tickets. Each project is scored on real adoption, revenue, and utilityâ€”rewarding substance over hype.

item.title: Developer Hackathon by {{Company}} & HackerNoon?
item.content:encoded: HackerNoon offers 6â€“12 month remote technology hackathons designed for sustained developer engagement rather than short-term hype. Instead of fleeting ads, sponsors get deep API adoption, compounding SEO value, and permanent technical content hosted for a monthly audience of 4M+ readers. Itâ€™s gamified marketing that builds a lasting developer ecosystem.

item.title: Living With the Lethal Trifecta: A Guide to Personal AI Agent Security
item.content:encoded: Iâ€™m convinced that personal AI agents are too powerful to ignore and too dangerous to deploy carelessly. I built one anyway. Here are practical security principles I use: dedicated accounts, Docker sandboxing, Tailscale closed network, tool policies with human approval, no third-party plugins, and full audit trails.

item.title: I asked the Portal One+ Telegram AI assistant to review itself. Here's how it went
item.content:encoded: Portal One+ is an open-source, self-hosted AI assistant that connects to Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, Discord, and others. It is like hiring a personal assistant who sits at your desk all day, but knows your world by day 30. The bot is built on the OpenClaw runtime, which is a stateless, persistent workspace.

item.title: Meet the Contest Winner: Fintech Architect Sibasis Padhi on Building Resilient Financial Systems
item.content:encoded: Sibasis Padhi is an expert in Agentic AI microservices and cloud performance optimization for financial systems. He wrote a winning entry for the HackerNoon Writing Contest. Padhi's article was born out of a real-world architectural dilemma.

item.title: When Family Wealth Becomes a Prison
item.content:encoded: Ernest Ivraine lives under his miserly fatherâ€™s shadow, quietly bearing the burdens of wealth and duty. While his brother Henry escapes to India for honor and freedom, Ernest guards his familyâ€™s interests and struggles with resentment, love, and moral obligation, facing a life where loyalty clashes with desire, and gold rules the fate of men.

item.title: A Life of Luxury Cannot Heal a Yearning Soul
item.content:encoded: In this chapter, a young woman endures the strict guidance of her governess, family pressure, and the unwanted attention of a conceited suitor. Despite wealth and comfort, she longs for the freedom and beauty of her childhood home. The story explores the conflict between societal expectation, personal independence, and the yearning for true happiness.

item.content:encoded: Comments

item.content:encoded: Comments

item.title: Show HN: A physically-based GPU ray tracer written in Julia
item.content:encoded: Comments

item.title: Why Stack Overflow and Cloudflare launched a pay-per-crawl model
item.content:encoded: Inside the pay-per-crawl model colaunched by Stack Overflow and Cloudflare.

item.title: Mind the gap: Closing the AI trust gap for developers
item.content:encoded: Developer trust is synonymous with a willingness to deploy AI-generated code to production systems with minimal human review, as well as assurance that AI tools arenâ€™t introducing unacceptable risks and technical debt that will burden you down the line.

item.title: Show HN: Rebrain.gg â€“ Doom learn, don't doom scroll
item.content:encoded: Comments

item.title: Data is the new oil, and your database is the only way to extract it
item.content:encoded: Ryan sits down with Shireesh Thota, CVP of Azure Databases at Microsoft, to discuss the evolution of databases at Microsoft; Azureâ€™s comprehensive portfolio that includes SQL Server, CosmosDB, and Postgres; and the challenges that come with database architecture, from the importance of cost governance and multi-cloud strategies to the future of databases when it comes to AI.

item.title: Show HN: Write native binary web apps with TypeScript and Express
item.content:encoded: Comments

item.title: Even your voice is a data problem
item.content:encoded: Recorded last December at AWS re:Invent, Ryan welcomes CEO and co-founder of Deepgram, Scott Stephenson, for a conversation on advancing voice AI technology.

item.title: How everyone and anyone can use AI for good
item.content:encoded: There are big hitters in the AI space that use this tech for humanitarian and environmental goodâ€”from start-ups fighting climate change to voice recognition experts diagnosing diseases. But you don't need to be backed by AWS or Microsoft to do good. In part two of this series, we dive into how anyone can use AI for good.

item.title: Is anyone using AI for good?
item.content:encoded: In a world where AI is replacing human workers, using up energy and water, and deepening disconnect, is AI for humanitarian good even possible? The answer is yes. In the first part of this two-part series, we're taking a look at just a few AI do-gooders and what they're doing to fight climate change, make healthcare more accessible, and help their communities.

item.title: The logos, ethos, and pathos of your LLMs
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Professor Tom Griffiths, the head of Princeton Universityâ€™s AI Lab, to dive into findings from his new book The Laws of Thought, which explores the history of the philosophy, mathematics, and logic that underlie artificial intelligence, and scientists' efforts to describe our minds using mathematics.

item.title: Why demand for code is infinite: How AI creates more developer jobs
item.content:encoded: Not only is there a future for software development, but weâ€™re on the cusp of enormous demand for code developed by humans.

item.title: AI attention span so good it shouldnâ€™t be legal
item.content:encoded: We have another two-for-one special this week, with two more interviews from the floor of re:Invent.

item.title: Code smells for AI agents: Q&A with Eno Reyes of Factory
item.content:encoded: Quality software still needs high-quality code, AI agents or not.

item.title: Generating text with diffusion (and ROI with LLMs)
item.content:encoded: Two guests for the price of one! This episode has two interviews recorded at AWS re:Invent back in December.

item.title: Whatâ€™s new at Stack Overflow: February 2026
item.content:encoded: This month, weâ€™ve launched several improvements to AI Assist, opened Chat to all users on Stack Overflow, launched custom badges across the network, and launched one of the first community-authored coding challenges.

item.title: Wanna see a CSS magic trick?
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Chris Coyier, founder of CSS Tricks and CodePen, to talk all about what the state of the art of CSS is today, including new features like variables and scroll-driven animations.

item.title: Scaling enterprise AI: lessons in governance and operating models from IBM
item.content:encoded: Successful implementation and scaling of enterprise AI projects is fundamentally a people and operating model challenge, not just a technology problem.

item.title: Are you learning with AI? We want to know about it!
item.content:encoded: We're running a survey to understand how people are using AI to learn and whether that's helping, hurting, and replacing tools.

item.title: Are bugs and incidents inevitable with AI coding agents?
item.content:encoded: What specific kind of bugs is AI more likely to generate? Do some categories of bugs show up more often? How severe are they? How is this impacting production environments?

item.title: Spy vs spy at scale
item.content:encoded: Ryan welcomes Anthony Vinci, former senior intelligence officer and author of The Fourth Intelligence Revolution, to explore AIâ€™s evolving role in intelligence in places like translation and image analysis, the challenges of evolving modern tech into government infrastructure, and the importance of democratized intelligence so citizens can keep themselves and loved ones safe.

item.title: Stack Gives Back 2025!
item.content:encoded: Weâ€™re excited to announce our 17th annual Stack Gives Back campaign donations.

item.title: AI can 10x developers...in creating tech debt
item.content:encoded: Ryan sits down with Michael Parker, VP of Engineering at TurinTech to discuss the newest kind of tech debtâ€”AI-generated tech debt. They dive into the uneven productivity results of AI tools, how tech teams are evolving their roles and work in response to these massive technological shifts, and what the nervous developer can do to maintain joy in their work.

item.title: Automate your security whack-a-mole: Q&A with Exaforce
item.content:encoded: Security controls can be a bit of a cat and mouse gameâ€”you block one attack, new ones spring up.

item.title: Is that allowed? Authentication and authorization in Model Context Protocol
item.content:encoded: Learn how to protect MCP servers from unauthorized access and how authentication of MCP clients to MCP servers works.

item.title: Donâ€™t let your backend write checks your frontend canâ€™t cache
item.content:encoded: Ryan welcomes Prakash Chandran, CEO and co-founder of Xano, to the show to discuss the intricate relationship between frontend and backend development, the potential challenges that universal frontend interfaces pose for developers, and the importance of understanding both your frontend and your backend when using AI code.

item.title: How AWS re:Invented the cloud
item.content:encoded: From the floor at AWS re:Invent, Ryan is joined by AWS Senior Principal Engineer David Yanacek to chat about all things AWS, from the truth behind AWSâ€™s Black Friday origin mythos to the development of essential cloud tools like SQS and DynamoDB. Plus, how David envisions autonomous agents will ease developers' operational burdens.

item.title: How Stack Overflow is taking on spam and bad actors
item.content:encoded: If a new post looks very similar to content that has been recently removed for being spam, it's likely spam too.

item.title: Transforming enterprise workflows: How IBM is unlocking AI's potential
item.content:encoded: Learn how IBM deployed and integrated AI tools in the ultimate enterprise environment.

item.title: If you're a Zoomer, this one's for you: Everything Gen Z needs to know about the 2025 tech landscape
item.content:encoded: Here's the lowdown on all the tech from 2025 that you, dear Zoomer, should know about.

item.title: 8 lessons from tech leadership on scaling teams and AI
item.content:encoded: What we learned from the first year of Leaders of Code.

item.title: Vibe code anything in a Hanselminute
item.content:encoded: Ryan welcomes back the mighty Scott Hanselman, VP of Developer Community at Microsoft, for a crossover episode about all things vibe coding.

item.title: Now everyone can chat on Stack Overflow
item.content:encoded: Registered users can now join public chat rooms from day one, making it easier to connect, learn, and participate in the community

item.title: Every ecommerce hero needs a Sidekick
item.content:encoded: Ryan is joined by Vanessa Lee, VP of Product at Shopify, to discuss how AI is a tech renaissance and how these new technologies are affecting the ecommerce world. They cover the development of Sidekick, along with the general challenges of building AI tools, the importance of maintaining human oversight in AI, and what the future holds for personalized user experiences in ecommerce.

item.title: You need quality engineers to turn AI into ROI
item.content:encoded: Pete Johnson, Field CTO, Artificial Intelligence at MongoDB, joins the podcast to say that looking at AIâ€™s impact as a job killer is a flawed metric.

item.title: Search engine bots crawled so AI bots could run
item.content:encoded: Ryan hosts Akamai data scientist Robert Lester on the show to discuss how the growth of AI bots affects internet traffic, the ways these AI bots differ from the original search engine optimization ones, and why you might not want to mitigate AI bots on your websites.

item.title: Whatâ€™s new at Stack Overflow: January 2026
item.content:encoded: For this first edition of the new year, weâ€™re taking a step back to highlight some of the most impactful features shipped over the last year and how they can help you start 2026 strong.

item.title: A new worst coder has entered the chat: vibe coding without code knowledge
item.content:encoded: In the age of AI, being able to make applications and create code has never been easier. But is it any good? Here's what vibe coding is like for someone without technical skills.

item.title: The most dangerous shortcuts in software
item.content:encoded: Ryan sits down with Tom Totenberg, head of release automation at LaunchDarkly, to discuss the perils of taking too many shortcuts in software development, how business pressures and AI code tools have contributed to dangerous corner cutting, and the importance of balancing speed with sustainability to maintain system integrity.

item.title: Documents: The architectâ€™s programming language
item.content:encoded: Senior developers know how to deploy code to systems made of code. Architects know how to deploy ideas to systems made of people.

item.title: A look under the hood: How (and why) we built Question Assistant
item.content:encoded: Evaluating question quality and determining the appropriate feedback required some classic ML techniques in addition to our GenAI solution.

item.title: A new era of Stack Overflow
item.content:encoded: Live from the stage of WeAreDevelopers, weâ€™re unveiling our new vision and mission for the future of Stack Overflow and our community.

item.title: How AI is helping us build better communities
item.content:encoded: MIT and Stanford professor Alex â€œSandyâ€ Pentland joins the show to explore the power of communities for shared knowledge and how AI could hurt or help the growth of these communities.
